author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Grandmother reveals she is still suffering with illness THREE YEARS after contracting food poisoning on family holiday to Sharm El Sheikh
text:
View
comments
A grandmother who fell ill with severe food poisoning while on holiday in Egypt in 2012 has revealed she is still suffering almost three years later.
Lillian Foote, 62, was struck down with a severe stomach illness after eating food served up by staff at a five star hotel just three days into her family holiday with her husband and granddaughter.
Up to 15 other holidaymakers were taken ill during their luxury getaway at the Hauza Beach Resort, Nabq Bay in Sharm El Sheikh.
Lillian Foote shows with the medication she now has to take some three years after first falling ill on holiday in Egypt
Although the trip took place as long ago as September 2012, Mrs Foote, from Warrington, Cheshire, still has stomach issues and other severe abdominal pains today and has been warned by doctors she will suffer 'ongoing' gastroenteritis for the forseeable future.
She has since been prescribed anti depressants to cope with her ordeal and has lost three stone.

No time to admire the view! Extreme parachute skiers... Today, Mrs Foote who has instructed a firm of personal injury lawyers to sue the tour operator which arranged the holiday said: 'Essentially I've had food poisoning for three years - it's unbelievable. I am still not eating because I am frightened. I am so paranoid I boil our water from the tap and put it in the fridge.
'Lots of people go on holiday and get ill but to be ill three years later is ridiculous. I thought this would have been a great holiday for Tia but we couldn't take her anywhere because we were bed ridden. We just all came back looking like zombies.
'I have been on many trips abroad and never had any problems. When you go abroad the whole point is to try the food but now I think I will never go abroad again. It was an absolute nightmare holiday from hell which I will never forget - just thinking about it makes me cry and I never thought I would be on anti-depressants because of a holiday.'
The Hauza Beach Resort, Nabq Bay in Sharm El Sheikh in Egypt where Lillian Foote was struck down with food poisoning
Lillian and granddaughter Tia swimming before becoming ill on their Egyptian holiday from hell
Lillian and her partner Geoff Humphries, 65, had spent Â£2,500 to take their seven year old granddaughter Tia to the Hauza Beach Resort in popular holiday destination, Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, for 10 days to help celebrate his remission from cancer.
On arrival they had breakfast, lunch and dinner at the hotel but three days into the trip the couple both complained of stomach cramps and soon became violently ill.
Lillian Foote stands with her partner Geoff at their home in Warrington
'At first I thought it was just Geoff and I adjusting to the travelling but Tia had only been eating boiled eggs and wasn't ill. Then we noticed up to 15 other holidaymakers sitting around the pool became unwell too and we had to fight to get the bathroom. It was a nightmare scenario.
'We had been really diligent about tap water - I don't even brush my teeth in it and we didn't touch it. But I think the kitchen staff washed their food in it.
'There was no bottled water in the room and all the cleaner could bring to our room was a one litre bottle of coke with the seal already broken. Staff wouldn't let me fill up my own water bottle at a plastic font - despite me needing to take my diabetes medication.
'There was uncooked meat lying out for long periods of time, flies surrounding the food. The hotel had a medical centre but it sent off for medication from Cairo that wasn't marked and had no instruction - and it turned out to be an antibiotic I was allergic to.
'Eventually we had to get to a taxi to the nearest chemist for tablets. At one stage we were living on crisps and we were unable to leave our hotel room for virtually the whole holiday. We didn't want to risk getting an earlier flight home for fear of being ill on the plane.'
Back home Mrs Foote took Kaolin and morphine which seemed to settle her stomach but as soon as she stopped taking it the symptoms returned. She has been scheduled for surgery as doctors found lumps and parasites in her intestines which they say are twisted.
She said: 'I thought the medication would clear my system but I couldn't take it anymore. I was that down that I was crying and crying and I was put on anti-depressants and I am still on them now. As soon as I feel that stomach pain I know what it is. It's crippling. I am still not eating because I am frightened to eat.
'I look at lettuce and think I need to wash it in boiled water. I know for a fact it will be safe in our tap water but I can't help it.
The holiday was supposed to be a time for fun and relaxation, but for Mrs Foote, it turned out very different
This photo shows Mrs Foote two months after returning from the Egypt holiday where she fell ill
'I am so unhappy this has ended up like this. It just does not seem to want to resolve itself. People talk about getting ill on holiday but having this for three years now is ridiculous. I just want to get it sorted out and want to help other in the same situation and prevent it happening again to someone else.
'Ever since we got back from our holiday I have continued to suffer from bowel problems which I may be stuck with permanently.'
Specialist travel lawyers at Irwin Mitchell, who are representing the couple, are also aware of other holidaymakers who have fallen ill at the resort in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2013 and 2014 while travel rating website Trip Advisor has received very mixed reviews for the hotel with one person claiming guests were 'getting taxis to Burger King'.
Irwin Mitchell has called on tour operator The Freedom Travel Group to work with them to resolve Lillian and Geoff's cases amicably without the need for formal court proceedings.
To date, no formal denial of liability has been received in respect of the claims and negotiations on behalf of Lillian and Geoff continue.
Mrs Foote has instructed lawyers to look into how and why she fell ill while on holiday in Sharm El-Sheikh
Clare Pearson, a specialist international personal injury lawyer, said: 'Lillian and Geoff were looking forward to taking their granddaughter Tia away for 10 days in Egypt.
'Unfortunately, as both Lillian and Geoff fell ill during their stay and throughout their holiday, the break was ruined.
'Over the years we have handled thousands of holiday illness cases and have seen just how devastating gastric problems can be for those affected.
'We have also represented dozens of clients who have also stayed at the Hauza Beach resort and fallen ill during their stay.'
A spokesperson for The Freedom Travel Group said: 'The Freedom Travel Group takes health and hygiene issues very seriously. We know how important holidays are to customers who book with us, and how upsetting it can be if they become unwell while overseas.
'We work closely with our partners to ensure the holidays we offer operate to the highest health and hygiene standards, so were sorry to hear about the Foote family's experience in Egypt in September 2012. We can confirm that we have recently been contacted by a solicitor acting on behalf of the party.
'Accordingly, as we are now in the process of liaising directly with their legal representatives we are unable to comment further at this time so as not to unduly influence any possible legal proceedings.'
MailOnline Travel has contacted the Hauza Beach Resort and is awaiting comment.
